headline.main: A Peace Plan for the Cigarette Wars

docs.lead_paragraph: It was a few days before Christmas, and the Massachusetts Attorney General, Scott Harshbarger, was holding forth with the fire-breathing wrath now standard in the national war against smoking. Bay State citizens "have paid too much in staggering human and financial costs for a poisonous product," Harshbarger thundered, before declaring that his state would become the fifth to sue for recovery of the tax dollars it had spent on health care for the customers of predatory cigarette manufacturers. He put the price at more than 10,000 lives and $200 million annually. The tobacco companies, the state's complaint asserted, "have developed sophisticated techniques to manipulate the nicotine delivery of cigarettes so as to create and sustain addiction in smokers" and have "systematically suppressed and concealed material information" based on "their own secret research, that their products eventually injure or kill the consumer when used exactly as intended." Unless stopped, Harshbarger said, "the tobacco industry will continue to deceive and defraud" the public, "while enticing our children to become its next generation of victims."

headline.main: Student's Death Is Linked to an Anesthetic

docs.lead_paragraph: A University of Rochester student from New York City who died two days after participating in a medical research project had been given too much topical anesthetic during a lung test, according to doctors at the university's medical center, Strong Memorial Hospital. Hoiyan Wan, a 19-year-old nursing student from Elmhurst, Queens, was paid $150 as a volunteer in a study on the effects of smoking and air pollution.

headline.main: Student Dies After Aiding In Research

docs.lead_paragraph: A University of Rochester sophomore from New York City, who was paid $150 to take part in a medical research project on smoking and air pollution, died of a heart attack on Sunday, two days after undergoing a lung procedure related to the research. The study, involving 48 volunteers, has been halted while the death is investigated. An autopsy will be conducted at the Monroe County Medical Examiner's office.
